source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Billet heating for beta quenching was done both by induction and by electric furnace to get two different soak times in the beta field. The soak time in the induction quench was only $9 0 \thinspace s$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: The bar was soaked for $1 5 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ in the electric furnace

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Both beat treatments were done at $1 0 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Quenching from the induction coil was done as single billets, both in cold agitated water at about $2 9 0 ~ \mathbf { K }$ and in static hot water at about $3 5 8 ~ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Quenching from the induction coil was done as single billets, both in cold agitated water at about $2 9 0 ~ \mathbf { K }$ and in static hot water at about $3 5 8 ~ \mathrm { K }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: All of the billets were extruded in the same manner using induction heating to approximately $9 2 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ for very short times before extrusion to an $8 0 { \cdot } \mathrm { m m }$ hollow

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: The temperatures of the anneals after the first cold reduction and before the last cold reduction were varied to produce cumulative annealing parameters from $2 . 3 ~ \times ~ 1 0 ^ { - 1 8 }$ to $2 9 \times 1 0 ^ { - 1 8 } \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Annealing parameters²3 were calculated using a value for the activation energy $Q$ of $8 0 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { K \ c a l / m o l }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Static autoclave corrosion tests at both 673 and $6 9 8 \mathrm { \bf K }$ at a pressure of $1 0 . 3 \mathrm { M P a }$ according to ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Samples of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2) were made at Sandvik Special Metals (SSM)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: Static autoclave corrosion tests at both 673 and $6 9 8 \mathrm { \bf K }$ at a pressure of $1 0 . 3 \mathrm { M P a }$ according to ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Samples of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2) were made at Sandvik Special Metals (SSM)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: The CEZUS research laboratory conducted tests only at $6 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: The grain size was about $1 . 4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in the bars heated for $1 5 ~ \mathrm { m i n }$ in the beta phase before quenching

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: compared to about $0 . 7 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ for the billets heated for only about $1 . 5 ~ \mathrm { { m i n } }$ in the induction system

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_012_chunk2
evidence_span: The outer surface exhibited a very fine quasi-martensitic needle-like structure with needle thicknesses measuring less than a micron

evidence_span: The precipitates present were also very fine with diameters less than 0.05 $\mu \mathrm { m }$

evidence_span: clearly show a minimum in the corrosion rate at about 20 to $4 0 ~ \mathrm { { K } }$ s
